title: Bamson Company Awards Institutions, Staff
text:
17:26 CET Bamson Company Awards Institutions, Staff By Daily Guide 
Bamson Company Limited, dealers in Sikkens Paints, recently honoured 10 institutions and 13 of its workers at an award and dinner ceremony held at the Alisa Hotel in Accra. 
The event formed part of activities marking the 30 th anniversary celebration of Bamson Company Limited. 
The institutions that were awarded for supporting Bamson Company included Emmkwab Trading Limited, A.Y. Asiamah Enterprise, Opoku Agyeman Enterprise and Kolours Limited. 
The rest were Toyota Ghana Company Limited, Kalmoni Group, CFAO Motors, Pasico and Mechanical Llyod. 
Workers of the Bamson Company, who were recognized for their dedication, included Constance Asante, who has served the company for about 28 years, Bismark Nii Ankrah and Daniel Ampadu, who have both served the company for 26 years. 
George Ansong and Theo Yaw Boakye have worked with the company for 25 years. 
The rest were Charles Ofori, Godfred Owusu, Philip Acheampong, Moses Mintah Sampong, Gifty Oduro Quansah, Cynthia Riberio, Emmanuel Yeboah Abankwah and George Debrah who have all contributed to the growth of the company for more than two decades. 
In his address, Managing Director of Bamson Group, Kwame Ofosu Bamfo traced the history of Bamson Company to 1983 when he worked in his father’s shop at Katamanso in Accra as sales attendant. 
According to him, during that time he realized that most customers preferred the Sikkens paints. 
Mr Bamfo said when he became an independent businessman, he decided not to sell any other paint brand except Sikkens. 
'We sold Sikkens paints and it was moving so fast from the selves and they were restocked from time to time,' Mr. Ofosu Bamfo said. 
'I took the decision not to sell the main GIHOC decorative paints that my father was selling but consider the sale of Sikkens paints.” 
Mr Bamfo added that he contacted the Sikkens Group in Holland and asked them to appoint him as the local representative in Ghana, adding that in 1985, he was given approval by the Group. 
'We are celebrating the 30th anniversary now because I was made the local representative of Sikkens in Ghana in 1985 after the contract with Reiss & Co had expired,' he said. 
Commenting on the operations of the company over the years, he stated that his outfit had trained sprayers and workshops both locally and internationally in the vehicle repair system. 
'To date, more than 10,000 sprayers have benefited from the Sikkens training locally with over 250 master sprayers also benefiting from training courses in the Netherlands,' Mr. Ofosu Bamfo added. 
According to him, from its humble beginnings 30 years ago, Bamson Company today boasts of seven branches, 39 distributors and 120 staff. 
He noted that his outfit donated GH¢10,000 to support the June 3 Accra Fire and Flood victims and the painting of the Adum Presbyterian JHS Block in Kumasi at a cost of GH¢20,000, among others. 
Special Representative of United Nations Secretary General and Head of the United Nations Office West Africa, Dr. Mohammed Ibn Chambas, who was the special guest of honour at the event, lauded the resilience of Mr. Ofosu Bamfo and urged other entrepreneurs to imitate his example. 
'The story of Sikkens in Ghana is a testimony to the entrepreneurship of Kwame. This success story is one that is worthy of research by the country’s business schools as a case study,' he said. 
Bamson Company has over the years received various industry awards including the Chartered Institute of Marketing Ghana (CIMG) Award.
